questions.question: If you eat too much you will get fat.
questions.description: A complex sentence has one main clause and one or more subordinate clauses. Clauses introduced by if are subordinate clauses.

questions.question: I will have a think and let you know.
questions.description: A compound sentence has two or more coordinate clauses. Clauses connected by the conjunction and are coordinate clauses.

questions.question: Having been there before he knew what to expect.
We got our roof blown off in the storm last week.
questions.description: The given sentence has just one finite verb (got) and hence one clause. A simple sentence has just one clause.

questions.question: I went to see him, but he told me to get out.
questions.description: A compound sentence has two or more coordinate clauses. Clauses connected by the conjunction but are coordinate clauses.

questions.question: It was John who paid for the drinks.
questions.description: The given sentence has one main clause and one subordinate adjective clause.

questions.question: My grandfather died in a hospital.
questions.description: The given sentence has just one finite verb and hence one clause. Therefore, it is a simple sentence.

questions.question: I thought it strange that she hadn’t written.
questions.description: The given sentence has one main clause and one subordinate clause and hence it is a complex sentence.

questions.question: I looked a real fool when I fell in the river.
questions.description: The given sentence has one main clause and one subordinate adverb clause.

questions.question: I wasn’t the cleverest but I was the most beautiful.
You don’t have to carry identity papers in England.
questions.description: The given sentence has just one finite verb and hence one clause. Therefore, it is a simple sentence.

questions.question: That’s the girl who lives in the flat upstairs.
questions.description: The given sentence has one main clause and one subordinate adverb clause.
